SubTopics: Use graphical displays to illustrate that Earth and its solar system are one of many in the Milky Way galaxy, which is one of billions of galaxies in the universe.
Content: A teacher asked a class to write the “cosmic address” of Massachusetts. A cosmic address is ordered from smallest to largest.
The first four parts of the cosmic address are shown below.
problems/MA22G8S/media/1a.jpg
Which of the following best completes the cosmic address of Massachusetts?

SubTopics: Obtain and communicate information on how data from past geologic events are analyzed for patterns and used to forecast the location and likelihood of future catastrophic events.
Content: The map shows some of the tectonic plates that form Earth's surface, and four areas labeled W, X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22G8S/media/2a.jpg
In which area is an earthquake most likely to occur?

SubTopics: Analyze data to describe the effect of distance and magnitude of electric charge on the strength of electric forces.
Content: Which of the following models has the greatest attractive electric force between the charged particles?

SubTopics: Explain the role of gravity in ocean tides, the orbital motions of planets, their moons, and asteroids in the solar system.
Content: The table shows the masses of four planets and the distance of each planet from the Sun.
problems/MA22G8S/media/4a.jpg
Based on the data in the table, on which planet does the Sun exert the greatest gravitational force?

SubTopics: Construct and interpret data and graphs to describe the relationships among kinetic energy, mass, and speed of an object.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Two students are riding identical bicycles on a level sidewalk. Student R has a mass of 55 kg and student S has a mass of 40 kg.
Both students are traveling at a speed of 3 m/s.
Determine whether student R has a larger, a smaller, or an equal amount of kinetic energy compared to student S. Explain your reasoning.
Student R is at rest, begins to ride, and then moves faster and faster.
Identify which graph (1, 2, or 3) best represents the relationship between student R's speed and kinetic energy. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Examine and interpret data to describe the role that human activities have played in causing the rise in global temperatures over the past century.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Human activities are playing a role in increasing greenhouse gases. The increase in greenhouse gases is causing a rise in global temperatures.
The model represents the movement of thermal energy through Earth's systems.
problems/MA22G8S/media/6a.jpg
Which arrow best shows the movement of thermal energy that is causing a rise in global temperatures?
Select THREE activities that would help reduce the amount of greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere.

A.Choice: using bicycles as a form of transportation

C.Choice: cutting down forests to build farms and cities

D.Choice: burning coal at power plants to make electricity

E.Choice: using solar panels to collect energy from the Sun

SubTopics: Use the concept of systems engineering to model inputs, processes, outputs, and feedback among components of a transportation, structural, or communication system.
Content: A homeowner and a builder discussed three parts of a system that were involved in replacing the shingles on the roof of the homeowner's home:

:ibox:• hammering a nail

• roof with new shingles

• tools
Which table correctly classifies each part of the system as an input, a process, or an output?

SubTopics: Research and communicate information about how transportation systems are designed to move people and goods using a variety of vehicles and devices. Identify and describe subsystems of a transportation vehicle, including structural, propulsion, guidance, suspension, and control subsystems.
Content: The diagram shows a toy sailboat with some parts labeled.
problems/MA22G8S/media/8a.jpg
The labeled parts of the sailboat have specific functions.

:ibox:• The sail provides the force needed to move the boat.

• The mast holds up the sail.

• The rudder steers the boat.
Which table correctly classifies each part of the sailboat as a structural, propulsion, or control subsystem?

SubTopics: Choose and safely use appropriate measuring tools, hand tools, fasteners, and common hand-held power tools used to construct a prototype.
Content: A student plans to build a bench like the one shown.
problems/MA22G8S/media/9a.jpg
The student has determined that the following steps need to be completed:

:ibox:• make measurements

• cut wood

• smooth edges

• attach pieces of wood together with fasteners
The student will use an electric sander, a screwdriver, and an electric saw to build the bench.
Select THREE other items the student should use to safely build the bench.

SubTopics: Interpret basic weather data to identify patterns in air mass interactions and the relationship of those patterns to local weather.
Content: The table shows weather data for three days in Boston.
problems/MA22G8S/media/10a.jpg
Select the TWO most likely explanations for the change in weather from June 1 to June 3.

A.Choice: A cold front moved into the area.

B.Choice: A warm front moved through the area.

C.Choice: A low pressure system moved into the area.

D.Choice: A high pressure system moved into the area.

E.Choice: A cold air mass stalled over a warm air mass in the area.

SubTopics: Conduct an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, how well the type of matter retains or radiates heat, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.
Content: A teacher performs an investigation by heating a 5.4 g piece of aluminum and placing it into a beaker of water. The table shows the temperatures before and after the aluminum was placed in the water.
problems/MA22G8S/media/11a.jpg

The teacher repeats the investigation using a larger, 20 g piece of aluminum heated to 100°C. Which of the following best explains what will happen to the final temperature of both the water and the 20 g piece of aluminum?

A.Choice: The temperature will be 28°C because both pieces of aluminum transfer heat energy at the same rate.

B.Choice: The temperature will be 28°C because both pieces of aluminum are heated to the same initial temperature.

C.Choice: The temperature will be lower than 28°C because the smaller piece of aluminum transfers heat energy more quickly than the larger piece of aluminum.

D.Choice: The temperature will be higher than 28°C because the larger piece of aluminum transfers more heat energy to the water than the small piece of aluminum.

SubTopics: Describe how relationships among and between organisms in an ecosystem can be competitive, predatory, parasitic, and mutually beneficial and that these interactions are found across multiple ecosystems.
Content: Which of the following BEST describes the role that hammerhead sharks play in the ecosystem?

A.Choice: The sharks act as a food source for clams, oysters, and scallops.

B.Choice: The sharks compete with cownose rays for access to nutrients in the environment.

C.Choice: The sharks break down the remains of zooplankton and phytoplankton, returning nutrients to the environment.

D.Choice: The sharks limit the population size of cownose rays, preventing them from overfeeding on clams, oysters, and scallops.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe that matter and energy are transferred among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem and that both matter and energy are conserved through these processes.
Content: The diagram represents one process that transfers energy in the marine ecosystem.
problems/MA22G8S/media/13a.jpg
The process occurs in which of the following organisms?

SubTopics: Analyze data to provide evidence that disruptions (natural or human-made) to any physical or biological component of an ecosystem can lead to shifts in all its populations.
Content: In recent decades, overfishing has led to large decreases in the sizes of shark populations. Biologists studying the effects of overfishing on marine ecosystems have hypothesized that a decrease in hammerhead sharks has led to a decrease in bay scallops.
Select TWO pieces of data that the biologists would most likely use to test their hypothesis.

A.Choice: the population counts for bay scallops

B.Choice: the number of times hammerhead sharks reproduce each year

C.Choice: the number of offspring produced from one mating between bay scallops

D.Choice: the number of hammerhead sharks in each of the marine ecosystems over time

E.Choice: the temperature of the water in which hammerhead sharks and bay scallops live

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for the effects of periods of abundant and scarce resources on the growth of organisms and the size of populations in an ecosystem.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
Cownose rays are an important part of the marine ecosystem.
Identify the ecological relationship (competitive, parasitic, or predatory) between cownose rays and oysters in the ecosystem. Explain your reasoning.

Describe what would most likely happen to the size of the cownose ray population (increase, decrease, or stay the same) if there were a large decrease in the phytoplankton population in the ecosystem. Explain your reasoning.
Based on the food web, describe what would most likely happen to the hammerhead shark population if the cownose rays were removed from the ecosystem. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Develop a model to explain how the energy of the Sun and Earth's gravity drive the cycling of water, including changes of state, as it moves through multiple pathways in Earth's hydrosphere.
Content: The diagram shows a model of the water cycle. Four steps of the water cycle are labeled W, X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22G8S/media/16a.jpg
Which change would most likely increase the movement of water during step W?

SubTopics: Plan and conduct an experiment involving exothermic and endothermic chemical reactions to measure and describe the release or absorption of thermal energy.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.

:ibox:1. Place a thermometer in a beaker of room-temperature water.

2. Add baking soda to the beaker of water and stir until the baking soda is no longer visible.

3. Add citric acid to the beaker and stir for 5 sec.
The students recorded observations in a lab notebook every 30 sec for 2 min. They made the following observations:

:ibox:• The temperature decreased.

• Bubbles formed.

• The color did not change.
Identify the type of energy that was measured by the thermometer.
Identify whether the reaction in the beaker was endothermic or exothermic. Explain your answer.
Show how the students should have set up the lab notebook to record their data. In the table shown on the next page, fill in the row and column headings using labels from the list below.

SubTopics: Explain the function of a communication system and the role of its components, including a source, encoder, transmitter, receiver, decoder, and storage.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
The diagram shows an example of a communication system for a United States Geological Survey (USGS) data collection site that collects information about water in a lake.
problems/MA22G8S/media/18a.jpg
What is the source of the message in this communication system?

D.Choice: the water data available on the internet

Content: Which of the following is the storage for this communication system?

SubTopics: Construct a prototype of a solution to a given design problem.
Content: A company is developing a new kind of camera. Which of the following BEST describes a prototype for the camera?

A.Choice: a full-size working version of the camera

B.Choice: a three-dimensional clay model of the camera

C.Choice: a list of the materials needed to build the camera

D.Choice: a drawing showing the different sides of the camera

SubTopics: Use informational text to describe that food molecules, including carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, are broken down and rearranged through chemical reactions forming new molecules that support cell growth and/or release of energy.
Content: When a person eats a sandwich, the person's digestive system breaks down the sandwich into food molecules.
Select TWO statements that describe how the food molecules are used by the person's body.

A.Choice: The food molecules deliver oxygen and remove wastes from cells.

B.Choice: The food molecules are used to produce energy for cell processes.

C.Choice: The food molecules store genetic information that is used to direct cell division.

D.Choice: The food molecules are assembled into larger molecules that are used for cell growth.
